head.ce:title: Enhanced photocatalytic activity of BiVO4 by co-grafting of metal ions and combining with CuBi2O4

ce:list-item.ce:para: Fe ion graft on BiVO4 increased the H2O2 formation but decreased the O2− formation.
Photocatalytic activity of BiVO4 was enhanced by grafting both Fe3+ and CoPi.
Combination with a p-type semiconductor CuBi2O4increased photocatalytic activity.
Grafting of Fe3+ on CuBi2O4 and CoPi on BiVO4 enhanced the activity of the composite.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In order to improve photocatalytic activity of BiVO4, the co-grafting effects of two kinds of co-catalysts for electron and hole separations were examined. At first, stabilization of electrons in BiVO4 by grafting Fe3+ was confirmed by analyzing the formation of O2− and H2O2 as reduction intermediates of O2. When BiVO4 was co-grafted with Fe3+ and CoPi as an electron separator and a hole separator, respectively, its photocatalytic activity for decomposition of gaseous acetaldehyde with visible light (470nm LED) was enhanced compared to the BiVO4 grafted only by either co-catalyst. This indicated that co-grafting is effective to increase photocatalytic activity because electron and hole were effectively taken out of the BiVO4. Furthermore, by combined with CuBi2O4, a p-type semiconductor, the photocatalytic activity of BiVO4 was also increased. This is because holes and electrons, which were generated in the both semiconductors, were successfully separated in BiVO4 and CuBi2O4, respectively, due to combination of electrons in the BiVO4 with holes in the CuBi2O4. To promote the reaction between electrons in BiVO4 and holes in CuBi2O4, we examined co-grafting effects of two kinds of co-catalyst to the composite by preparing the Cu/CuBi2O4–CoPi/BiVO4 photocatalyst. The photocatalytic activity was further enhanced when it was prepared in a suitable procedure that enables us to graft the reduction and oxidation co-catalysts only at each site.

ce:section.ce:para: Photocatalytic materials have been used in wide application such as air purification, water purification, anti-virus and water splitting [1,2]. Photocatalytic reaction proceeds owing to holes and electrons generated in materials by absorbing light energy. The photogenerated holes have an oxidation ability and the photogenerated electrons have a reduction ability. For decomposition of organic pollutants by photocatalytic reaction, the oxidation potential of hole needs to be more positive than +1V that is redox potential of general organic compounds. In addition, the redox potential of electrons needs to be more negative than that of oxygen (O2/O2− or H2O2) because surplus electrons that are not consumed by reduction of oxygen would increase the electron–hole recombination probability. Many materials for photocatalyst, which meet these conditions, have been reported such as TiO2, SrTiO3, ZnO, ZrO2, WO3, and BiVO4 [3–6]. Among these materials, BiVO4 has attracted much attention in the recent years as one of the visible-light driven photocatalysts because of non-toxicity and its relatively narrow bandgap of ~2.4eV in monoclinic crystalline form. However, photocatalytic activity of BiVO4 is generally low compared to TiO2 and WO3 photocatalysts because the electronic potential in the valence band of BiVO4 is more negative than those of TiO2 and WO3, which means weak oxidation ability against objects [7]. Since photocatalytic activity of BiVO4 is easily influenced by crystalline phase, crystallinity, and morphology, enhancement of its photocatalytic activity was achieved by improvement of preparation process [8].

The other methods for enhancement of photocatalytic activity are grafting co-catalysts. There are two kinds of co-catalysts in terms of its function: one is for separation of electrons and the other is for separation of holes. The former representative co-catalysts are Pt, Fe3+, and Cu2+ [9–12]. It was reported that Fe3+ and Cu2+ were grafted as amorphous oxide cluster [9,10], and reduced into Fe2+ and Cu+ by receiving one electron, respectively [11,12]. The reduced metal oxide cluster with reduced ions could return into the original state by giving more than one electron to molecular oxygen. The latter ones are CoOx, CoPi (CoPOx), IrOx, and RuOx which are used for water oxidation, among which CoPi is reported to be the most effective co-catalyst for water oxidation [13]. However, there were few reports concerning co-grafting effects on photocatalytic activity especially in gaseous phase. We expected that by co-grafting of both co-catalysts for separations of electrons and holes, photocatalytic activity in gaseous phase would be further enhanced. Moreover, complex of BiVO4 with the other materials of p-type semiconductor is also effective for enhancing photocatalytic activity.

In the present work, we examined the co-grafting effects of two kinds of co-catalysts for separation of electrons and holes and the combining effect with the other materials on the photocatalytic activity of BiVO4. Candidate co-catalysts were Fe3+ and Cu2+ for electron separators and CoPi for a hole separator in view of their performances and cost. For a candidate of combined material, we selected CuBi2O4 which is a p-type semiconductor with bandgap of 1.5eV. Since the top of the valence band of CuBi2O4 is around −1.0V (vs. SHE at pH 0) [14] and the bottom of the conduction band of BiVO4 is around 0V (vs. SHE at pH 0), we expect that photogenerated holes in CuBi2O4 can react with electrons in BiVO4. Furthermore, co-grafting effect of co-catalyst on the photocatalytic activity of the CuBi2O4 and BiVO4 composite (CuBi2O4–BiVO4) was examined for enhancing photocatalytic activity of BiVO4.

BiVO4 powder used was provided by Alfa Aesar. CuBi2O4 powder in tetragonal form was prepared by solid-phase synthesis from the stoichiometric mixture of CuO and Bi2O3 at 973K for 24h in air. The formation of CuBi2O4 was confirmed from its XRD pattern.

Fe3+ or Cu2+ was grafted on each photocatalyst by impregnation method. 10mL of distilled water was added to a mixture of FeCl3·6H2O or CuCl2·2H2O and 1g of photocatalysts. The FeCl3·6H2O or CuCl2·2H2O was weighted so that the weight fraction of Fe or Cu relative to each photocatalyst was 0.025–0.2wt%. Each mixed solution was heated at 90°C for 1h under stirring. The solution was centrifuged and then the solid powder was sufficiently washed with distilled water. The obtained powder was dried at 110°C for 24h.

CoPi was grafted on BiVO4 grains by photochemical deposition method. Potassium phosphate buffer solution of 0.1M adjusted to pH 7, containing the desired amount of CoCl2 and BiVO4 powder, was irradiated for 1 hour by a 150W Xe lamp. The CoCl2 was weighted so that the weight fraction of Co relative to each photocatalyst was 0.5–1.5wt%. The powder was washed with distilled water and dried.

CuBi2O4–BiVO4 composites were prepared by mixing CuBi2O4 and BiVO4 powders in the desired weight ratios, that is, CuBi2O4/(CuBi2O4+BiVO4)=0.1–0.5. After the mixing, the powder was usually heat treated at 150°C for 3h.

Optical absorption spectra of photocatalyst powders were measured using a probe spectrometer (Avantes, Inc.) consisting of AvaSpec-2048, AvaLight-DH-S-BAL, and a reflection probe. The recorded reflectance was converted to Kubelka–Munk function which corresponds to the absorbance.

Photocatalytic activities were measured for the acetaldehyde as follows. Photocatalyst powder of 0.15g was spread on a Petri dish of 4cm diameter and then the dish was placed in the circulated reactor (270cm3 in volume) with mixed gas of O2/N2=1:4. The acetaldehyde gas of 100μL and liquid water of 10μL were injected into the reactor. The dish placed in the reactor was irradiated by a LED of λ=470nm at the intensity of 20mW/cm2, and the amount of generated CO2 was monitored by a gas analyzer (LI-COR, LI-840) equipped in the circulation reactor system [12].

The generation of O2− was observed by using a luminol chemiluminescence probe method [15]. Photocatalyst of 15mg was added in 0.01M NaOH solution of 3.5mL in a quartz cell (1cm×1cm) and then the suspension was irradiated by a He–Cd laser (KIMMON, IK5652R-G) at λ=442nm with 14mW. After the irradiation, 50μL of 7mM luminol solution was immediately added in the suspension. The chemiluminescence intensity was measured using a Peltier-cooled photon-counter head (Hamamatsu Photonics, H7421).

For the measurements of H2O2, the photocatalyst suspension was irradiated by the laser and then was kept in dark to eliminate O2−. 50μL of 7mM luminol solution was added in the suspension and then the suspension was kept in dark for 10min. 50μL of hemoglobin solution was added in the suspension and then the chemiluminescence intensity was measured. To convert the chemiluminescence intensities to the absolute concentration of O2− and H2O2, the apparatus factor was calculated from the experiment where all luminol molecules are consumed for the reaction with an excess amount of H2O2.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Grafting effects of co-catalysts for electron and hole separations
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 1 shows UV–vis spectra of BiVO4, Fe3+ grafted BiVO4 (Fe/BiVO4), Cu2+ grafted BiVO4 (Cu/BiVO4), and CoPi grafted BiVO4 (CoPi/BiVO4) photocatalyst powders. The absorption intensity of the BiVO4 starts to increase at around 520nm. Those of the Fe/BiVO4 and Cu/BiVO4 were almost the same as the BiVO4. This observation is different from the cases of Fe/TiO2 and Cu/TiO2 photocatalyst powders, where the absorption shoulder was observed at longer wavelength region than the absorption edge, due to the direct electron transfer from valence band of TiO2 to the grafted Fe or Cu ions [9–12]. If the direct electron transfer from valence band of BiVO4 to the grafted Fe or Cu ions would occur, the absorption shoulder at the absorption edge should be observed. Although the electronic potential of conduction band of BiVO4 is more negative than those of Fe3+/Fe2+ or Cu2+/Cu+ [16], the direct electron transfer from the valence band of the BiVO4 to the grafted Fe or Cu ions did not take place. Also for CoPi/BiVO4, new absorption did not appear. This indicated that by grafting CoPi, new electronic excitation, for example from the BiVO4 valence band to the CoPi, did not occur.

For BiVO4, its valence band consists of Bi6s or hybrid Bi6s–O2p [6] and therefore valence electrons are localized at a Bi atom or between Bi and O atoms. By using a quantum mechanical terms, transition dipole moment for light absorption is determined by one center integral. In other words, wave functions, or electron distributions, must be overlapped between the ground state and the excited state to have a light absorption. Therefore, in the present case, when chemical bond of BiOFe or BiOCu is formed by grafting Fe or Cu ions on the BiVO4 surface, the electronic excitation by light irradiation would be difficult to occur within the OFe or OCu bond. On the other hand, the valence band of TiO2 mainly consists of O2p orbitals. Therefore electrons in the valence band possibly involve O atoms next to the grafted metal ions, and they could be excited to the metal ions.

Fig. 2 shows the amounts of CO2 generated in 1h by photocatalytic decomposition of gaseous acetaldehyde under visible light irradiation with 470nm LED. For the bare BiVO4 alone, a small amount of CO2 of 3ppm/h was observed, indicating that probability of electron–hole recombination was high. In contrast, when Fe ions were grafted on the BiVO4 surface, photocatalytic activity was increased up to 30ppm/h at Fe grafting ratio of 0.1wt%.

To examine the role of Fe ions, the amounts of O2− and H2O2 generated under visible light irradiation at λ=442nm was measured and the experimental results are shown in Fig. 3. For the bare BiVO4, O2− was preferentially generated compared to H2O2. This indicated that the electron photoproduced at the conduction band directly reduced O2 into O2− because electronic potential of the conduction band bottom of BiVO4 is around −0.42V (vs. SHE at pH 7) which is more negative than that of O2/O2−=−0.033V (vs. SHE at pH 7). In contrast, for Fe/BiVO4, the amount of O2− was decreased while that of H2O2 was increased. This indicated that the grafted Fe ions which receive electrons can reduce O2 into H2O2. Therefore, the redox potential of Fe3+/Fe2+ in the grafted Fe ions may be near to the redox potential of (O2, 2H+)/H2O2 of +0.695V (vs. SHE at pH 0). The Fe ions would receive electrons from conduction band not from the direct transfer from valence band as shown in Fig. 4(a). The amount of generated H2O2 seems to be somewhat small. We considered that the generated H2O2 would decompose into H2O and O2 by disproportionation due to a catalytic effect of the grafted Fe ions. For the Cu/BiVO4, the photocatalytic activity was increased similarly to the case of the Fe/BiVO4. Considering that redox potential of Cu2+/Cu+=+0.16 (vs. SHE at pH 0), Cu ions can also receive electrons from conduction band like Fe ions, indication that Cu ions also played an important role for electron separation. Based on previous a report [11], Cu ions which receive electrons would reduce O2 into O2−.7)

For the CoPi/BiVO4, the photocatalytic activity was also increased. Based on a previous report, Co2+ turns to Co3+ or Co4+ by giving one or two electrons to the valence band of host materials and then generated Co4+ can oxidize H2O into O2 [13]. In the present work, photocatalytic decomposition of gaseous acetaldehyde would be achieved by the same reaction mechanism. Hence it was concluded that CoPi played a role for hole separation (Fig. 4(c)). The increase of photocatalytic activity of CoPi/BiVO4 would be attributed to the suppression of electron–hole recombination by the effective hole separation although the oxidation potential of Co4+/Co2+ is more negative than that of BiVO4 valence band. Among single grafted co-catalysts used, 1.0wt%-CoPi/BiVO4 showed the highest photocatalytic activity of 49ppm/h, which was about 16 times as high as the bare BiVO4.

In the case of single grafting of co-catalyst, by changing grafting ratio alone, the increment of photocatalytic activity was restricted. Therefore, further charge separation by co-grafting of co-catalysts for electron and hole separations is needed for enhancing photocatalytic activity. The recombination caused by remained free carrier for single grafting can be suppressed by co-grafting. Fe ions are randomly grafted on the BiVO4 surface and, in contrast, CoPis are selectively grafted on the oxidation site of the BiVO4 surface by photodeposition. Owing to the control of each grafting procedure, one could graft Fe3+ and CoPi at each different site. Thus, we grafted 1.0wt%-CoPi on the BiVO4 after grafting 0.1wt%-Fe ions to prevent the grafting of the CoPi onto the Fe ions, which would promote a reverse reaction. The co-grafted BiVO4 showed further high photocatalytic activity of 63ppm/h compared to the single grafted BiVO4, which was 21 times as high as the bare BiVO4. This indicates that both electrons and hole were successfully taken out of the BiVO4 as illustrated in Fig. 4(d).

Fig. 5 shows UV–vis spectra of CuBi2O4–BiVO4 composites. The absorption intensity of the CuBi2O4 alone starts to increase at around 850nm. The spectra of the CuBi2O4–BiVO4 composites were combined by summing the absorptions of the bare BiVO4 and CuBi2O4. Therefore, BiVO4 was simply contacted with CuBi2O4 and did not react with CuBi2O4 at their interface.

Fig. 6 shows amounts of CO2 generated in one hour by photocatalytic decomposition of gaseous acetaldehyde under visible light irradiation at λ=470nm. For the bare CuBi2O4, photocatalytic activity was not observed at all. Even after the Cu and Fe ions were grafted on the CuBi2O4, the photocatalytic activity was not observed (data not shown). This is due to the CuBi2O4 valence band top of +1.0V (vs. SHE at pH 0), which is too negative to decompose organic pollutants. In contrast, for the CuBi2O4–BiVO4 composites, photocatalytic activities appeared. This indicated that the electrons photogenerated in the BiVO4 reacted with the holes photogenerated in the CuBi2O4 and then the remained holes and electrons were successfully separated in BiVO4 and CuBi2O4, respectively, because BiVO4 and CuBi2O4 alone show little or no photocatalytic activity. The maximum photocatalytic activity of 22ppm/h was obtained at the weight ratio, CuBi2O4/(CuBi2O4+BiVO4), of 0.2, or CuBi2O4:BiVO4=1:4, though the obtained maximum activity was lower than the cases of grafting co-catalysts shown in Fig. 2.

Based on the UV–vis reflectance spectra, absorption intensity at λ=470nm for CuBi2O4 was higher than that of BiVO4, though the absorbance ratio between two materials could not be estimated from Fig. 5. Since the component ratio (4:1) of BiVO4 presented the maximum activity, the absorption of CuBi2O4 at 470nm should be 4 times larger than that of BiVO4 to balance the number of photons absorbed in each semiconductor. As stated above, the maximum activity obtained was smaller than that obtained by grafting co-catalyst. Namely, to increase the photocatalytic activity, grafting of co-catalyst was effective because the co-catalyst was strongly adsorbed on the photocatalyst surface, leading to smooth electron transfer. In contrast, for the CuBi2O4–BiVO4 composite, electron transfer through the interface between BiVO4 and CuBi2O4 is difficult to occur because electron–hole recombination probability in each semiconductor was high.

To increase the frequency of recombination between electrons photogenerated in BiVO4 and holes photogenerated in CuBi2O4, we examined the grafting of co-catalyst on the CuBi2O4–BiVO4 composite. CoPi as a hole trap was grafted on the BiVO4 and Cu2+ as an electron trap was grafted on the CuBi2O4. Where the weight ratio of the composite was fixed to 0.2. Its photocatalytic activity was largely increased to 185ppm/h as shown in Fig. 6. This value was about 60 times as high as that of the bare BiVO4 and higher than that of the BiVO4 co-grafted with Fe3+ and CoPi shown in Fig. 2. This indicates that electrons, which have been stabilized in the BiVO4 by grafting CoPi, can easily react through the interface with holes in the CuBi2O4, which have been stabilized by grafting Cu2+. This effective separation process is schematically shown in Fig. 7.

Next, we prepared the co-catalyst grafted composite by grafting Cu2+ and then CoPi after mixing CuBi2O4 and BiVO4 in the weight ratio of 0.2. Its photocatalytic activity was decreased to 84ppm/h (data not shown in Fig. 6). This is due to the obstruction of oxidation site because Cu2+ was randomly adsorbed on the composite surface, resulting in the promotion of reverse reaction. Therefore, it is important for this composite photocatalysts that co-catalysts for electron and hole separations could be grafted only at reduction site and oxidation site, respectively. In other words, Cu2+ should be grafted on CuBi2O4 before the preparation of CuBi2O4–BiVO4 composite. Thus, it was demonstrated that, by a suitable grafting procedure, co-catalysts can also enhance the activity of composite photocatalysts.

We examined the effects of grafting of two kinds of co-catalysts on the photocatalytic activity of BiVO4. For the BiVO4 co-grafted with Fe3+ and CoPi as electron and hole separators, respectively (Fig. 4(d)), its photocatalytic activity was enhanced compared to the cases of single co-catalyst grafting for electron or hole separation (Fig. 4(b) and (c)). Therefore, co-grafting was demonstrated to be effective for enhancing photocatalytic activity because electron and hole were effectively stabilized. Furthermore, by composited with CuBi2O4, the photocatalytic activity was also increased. This is because electrons photogenerated in the BiVO4 reacted with holes that photogenerated in the p-type CuBi2O4 semiconductor and then holes and electrons were successfully separated in BiVO4 and CuBi2O4, respectively. In addition, it was revealed that co-grafting of two kinds of co-catalyst to the composite was effective to promote the reaction between electrons in BiVO4 and holes in CuBi2O4 (see Fig. 7), leading further enhancement of the photocatalytic activity.
